Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the number of teaching principals in the education system; the number of such teachers in each of the past three years who have taken early retirement; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is being compiled in my Department and will be forwarded to her.

With effect from 1 September 2000, administrative principals are appointed to all schools with seven or more mainstream class teachers. In addition, schools with a principal plus 11 or more teachers, including ex-quota posts, may appoint an administrative principal.

Teaching principals are now released from teaching duties for a specific number of days per year to enable them undertake administrative leadership and management functions. My Department will pay substitution costs for the days in question. I have recently approved a 100% increase in the number of days for which teaching principals can be released from teaching duties.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Fees.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: his plans in respect of assisting part-time and evening students who do not presently qualify for free fees; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Under the free fees initiative, the State meets the tuition costs of eligible students, who are attending full-time undergraduate courses, which must generally be of at least two years duration, at approved colleges.

MainHeading.P: The question of introducing free fees for part-time students generally, similar to those given to full time students, could only be considered having regard to overall resource constraints and other competing demands in the education sector. However, the White Paper on Adult Education, “Learning for Life”, indicates that arrangements will be implemented so that higher education fees, in respect of certain courses, will not apply to part-time students, who satisfy the residency clause, and who are social welfare means-tested or unemployment payment recipients or dependants, medical card holders or dependants, persons in receipt of family income supplement or dependants.

The Finance Act, 1996, as amended by the Finance Act, 1997, provides for tax relief, at the standard rate, for tuition fees paid in respect of approved part-time undergraduate courses which are of a minimum duration of two years and are followed in colleges approved for the higher education grants scheme or in colleges which satisfy the prescribed codes of standards.

In the 1997 Finance Act provision was made to extend tax relief, at the standard rate, for tuition fees paid in respect of approved part-time undergraduate courses operated by colleges in any EU member state providing distance education in the State.
In relation to the above reliefs, the maximum level of qualifying fees is £2,500.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the extent to which the current industrial dispute affects the level of service at Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare with consequent hardships to parents, teachers and students, particularly students sitting examinations; and if he will initiate any new discussions with ASTI with a view to an early resolution.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the impact of the current industrial dispute on the quality and extent of education available at St. Mary's College, Naas, County Kildare and on other schools and colleges; if his attention has further been drawn to the potential for the dispute to continue indefinitely with consequent damage to students particularly to those preparing for exams; his views on whether there is an urgent need to meet with the teachers in order to establish dialogue leading to trust and eventual agreement; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 258 and 262 together.

I am fully aware that the industrial action by the ASTI has resulted in the loss of eight days teaching for the vast majority of second level students. I am also deeply concerned that the ASTI are continuing with another strike on 14 December with further industrial action threatened for January 2001.

I fully appreciate the hardship being caused to parents and students by the ASTI action and the anxiety the disruption of normal teaching is causing for parents and students, especially students sitting examinations.

I have written to the ASTI yesterday outlining my views on the dispute and inviting them to meet me so that we can find a way to resolve this dispute in a mutually acceptable and satisfactory way in the interests of the students.
Questions Nos. 259, 260 and 261 withdrawn.
Question No. 262 taken with Question No. 258.
